tn.text: Chapters 7 and 8 were not in chronological order. They happened while Belshazzar was still the king. Chapter 9 now returns to the events of the reign of Darius who became king in chapter 6.

tn.ref: It was Ahasuerus who had been made king over the realm of the Babylonians
tn.text: This is background information about who Ahasuerus was. The UDB places this in parentheses to make that clear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: who had been made king over the realm of the Babylonians
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "who became king over the realm of the Babylonians" or "who conquered the Babylonians" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"over the country" or "over the kingdom"
This is the name of God that he revealed to his people in the Old Testament. See the translationWord page about Yahweh concerning how to translate this.

tn.ref: there would be seventy years until Jerusalem's abandonment would end
tn.text: "from the time Jerusalem was destroyed, it would remain in ruins for 70 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
this means no one would help or rebuild Jerusalem during that time

tn.ref: I turned my face to the Lord God
tn.text: Here "face" represents Daniel's attention. AT: "I focused my attention on the Lord God" or "I directed my thoughts toward the Lord God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Those who want to know Yahweh and please him are spoken of as if they are literally seeking to find Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: fasting, wearing sackcloth, and sitting in ashes
tn.text: These are symbolic acts of repentance and sorrow. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: I made confession of our sins
tn.text: "I confessed our sins"

tn.ref: you are the one who keeps the covenant and is faithful to love those
tn.text: "you do what what you said you would do in your covenant, and you faithfully love those"
Daniel continues praying to the Lord about the people of Israel.

tn.ref: We have sinned and have done what is wrong
tn.text: These two phrases express one idea in two different ways for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: We have acted wickedly and we have rebelled
tn.text: These two phrases express one idea in two different ways for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
The words "commands" and "decrees" share similar meanings and refer to the whole law. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: We have not listened to your servants
tn.text: Here "not listened" means they did not obey their message. AT: "We have not obeyed the message of your prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "name" refers to God's authority. AT: "spoke with your authority" or "spoke as your representative" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "land" refers to Israel. AT: "the Israelite people" (UDB)
Daniel continues praying to the Lord about the people of Israel.

Being righteous is spoken of as if "righteousness" were an object that belongs to Yahweh. The abstract noun "righteousness" can be stated as an action. AT: "Lord, you act justly" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: To us today, however, belongs shame on our faces—for the people
tn.text: Being ashamed is spoken of as if "shame" were an object that belongs to people. The abstract noun "shame" can be stated as a verb. AT: "But as for us, we are ashamed of what we have done—the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The word "us" includes Daniel and the Israelites, but it does not include God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
This idiom means their shame is visible to all. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: because of the great treachery that we committed against you
tn.text: "because we greatly betrayed you" or "because we were very unfaithful to you" (UDB)
Daniel continues praying to the Lord about the people of Israel.

tn.ref: To the Lord our God belong compassion and forgiveness
tn.text: Having these traits is spoken of as if they belonged to the Lord. AT: "The Lord our God is compassionate and forgives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: We have not obeyed the voice of Yahweh our God
tn.text: Here "voice" refers to the commands that Yahweh spoke. AT: "We have not obeyed what Yahweh told us to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The words "turned aside" mean that Israel stopped obeying God's laws. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: that are written in the law of Moses
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that Moses wrote about in the law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: have been poured out on us
tn.text: The abundance of the curse and the oath are spoken of as if they were poured out like water. This can be stated in active form. AT: "you have brought upon us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Daniel continues praying to the Lord about the people of Israel.

tn.ref: For under the whole of heaven ... what has been done to Jerusalem
tn.text: Daniel is exaggerating to show his great sorrow about Jerusalem. Many cities had been totally destroyed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: there has not been done anything
tn.text: "nothing has been done"

tn.ref: what has been done to Jerusalem
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "what you have done to Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: As it is written in the law of Moses
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "As Moses wrote in the law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here stopping evil activity is spoken of as turning away from them. AT: "stopping our evil actions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Yahweh has kept the disaster ready
tn.text: "Yahweh has prepared this disaster"

tn.ref: we have not obeyed his voice
tn.text: Here "voice" refers to the things that Yahweh commanded. AT: "we have not done what he told us to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "mighty hand" is a metonym for strength. AT: "with great strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you have made a famous name for yourself, as in this present day
tn.text: "you caused people to know how great you are, as you still do today"

tn.ref: still we sinned; we have done wicked things
tn.text: These two clauses mean basically the same thing and are used together to emphasize how bad sin is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: we sinned; we have done wicked things
tn.text: Daniel and Israel sinned and did wicked things, but "we" does not include God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
The words "anger" and "wrath" mean basically the same thing and emphasize how terrible God's anger is when he acts on it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This mountain may be holy because God's temple is there. AT: "the mountain where your holy temple is"
Here "our" refers to Daniel and Israel, but not to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
"a target of disrespect"
This does not mean "at this moment", but it is a way to show that the next phase in Daniel's prayer is about to start.

tn.ref: your servant ... his pleas for mercy
tn.text: The words "your servant" and "his" here refer to Daniel. He speaks about himself in the third person as a sign of respect for God. (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
"requests for mercy"
The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably as if Yahweh's face shone a light. AT: "act kindly toward" (UDB) or "act with favor toward" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to the temple in Jerusalem.

To "open the ears" is an idiom that means to listen. These two phrases means the same thing and emphasize Daniel's desire for God to listen to his prayer. AT: "please listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

To "open the eyes" is an idiom that means to see. These two phrases means the same thing and emphasize Daniel's desire for God to pay attention to his prayer. AT: "notice us" or "pay attention" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here "name" represents ownership. AT: "is your city" or "belongs to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be stated in positive form. AT: "act quickly"
"the people of Israel to whom I belong"
The mountain may be holy because of the temple. AT: "the mountain where God's holy temple is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the same angel Gabriel who appeared in the form of a man in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:08:15|8:16]]. AT: "Gabriel, who appeared as a man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: in the vision at the first
tn.text: This may refer to the first vision that Daniel had while he was awake. AT: "in the previous vision" or "in the vision I saw before" or "in a vision before"

tn.ref: flew down to me in rapid flight
tn.text: "flew down to me quickly"

tn.ref: at the time of the evening sacrifice
tn.text: The Jewish people sacrificed to God each evening just before the sun went down.
The words "insight" and "understanding" mean the same thing and emphasize that Gabriel will help Daniel to understand the message completely. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God gave the order" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "word" refers to the entire message. AT: "think about this message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This refers back to the prophesy of Jeremiah in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:09:01|9:2]].

tn.ref: Seventy sevens of years ... seven sevens ... and sixty-two sevens
tn.text: two sevens** - This is not the normal way the Israelites counted. If possible, try to translate in a way that preserves this use of the number seven. AT: "Seventy times seven years ... seven times seven years ... and sixty-two times seven years"

tn.ref: Seventy sevens of years are decreed for your people and your holy city to
tn.text: God decreed that he would do the things in this verse for the people and the holy city.

tn.ref: your people and your holy city
tn.text: The word "your" here refers to Daniel. The people are the Israelites and the holy city is Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: to end the guilt and put an end to sin
tn.text: The idea is repeated to emphasize how certain it is that this will happen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here "carry out" is an idiom that means to accomplish. AT: "to accomplish the vision" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
These words in this context mean the same thing. They ensure Daniel that Jeremiah's vision was indeed a prophecy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These words are used together to make the importance clear. AT: "You must clearly understand" or "You must know for sure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Anointing is a symbolic act to show that someone is chosen. AT: "the person that God anoints" or "the person that God chooses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
two sevens** - These added together are 69 of the 70 sevens spoken of in verse 24.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "People will rebuild Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
a deep ditch around a city or building, usually with water in it
"a time of great trouble"

two sevens of** - This is not the normal way the Israelites counted. If possible, try to translate in a way that preserves this use of the number seven. See how you translated this number in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:09:24|9:25]]. AT: "sixty-two times seven"

tn.ref: the anointed one will be destroyed and will have nothing
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "people will destroy the anointed one and he will have nothing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Anointing is a symbolic act to show that someone is chosen. See how you translated this title in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:09:24|9:25]]. AT: "the person that God anoints" or "the person that God chooses"
This is a foreign ruler, not "the anointed one." AT: "a foreign ruler who will come" or "a powerful ruler who will come"

tn.ref: Its end will come with a flood
tn.text: The army will destroy the city and the holy place just as a flood destroys things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This can be stated in active form. AT: "God has decreed ruin for the city and sanctuary" or "God has declared that the enemy army will destroy everything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to the coming ruler who will destroy the anointed one.

tn.ref: one seven ... In the middle of the seven
tn.text: Here "seven" is used to refer to a period of seven years. AT: "seven years ... Halfway through the seven years"
"stop" or "halt"

These words basically mean the same thing. The repetition is to show that the ruler will prevent all types of sacrifices. AT: "all forms of sacrificing" or "every type of offering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

This may refer to the defensive structures on top of the walls of the temple, which are called "abominations" because they are full of idols. AT: "the walls of the temple that are full of abominations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"a person who completely destroys"

tn.ref: A full end and destruction are decreed to be poured out
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God has decreed that he will pour out a full end and destruction" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
These two words or expressions are basically the same. They emphasize how serious and complete the destruction will be. AT: "Complete destruction" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: the one who has made the desolation
tn.text: "the person who caused the destruction"
